user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of read_cb:
```c
static ssize_t
read_cb (void *cls, uint64_t pos, char *mem, size_t size)
{
  struct Holder *holder = cls;
  void *src;
  void *buf;
  ssize_t ret;
  size_t offset;
  size_t r_size;

  if (pos > SSIZE_MAX)
    return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR;
  offset = (size_t) pos;
  src = malloc (size);
  if (NULL == src)
    return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR;
  r_size = fread (src, 1, size, holder->file);
  if (0 == r_size)
  {
    ret = (0 != ferror (holder->file)) ?
          MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR : MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_OF_STREAM;
    goto done;
  }
  if (MHD_YES != compress_buf (&holder->stream, src, r_size, &offset, &buf,
                               &size, holder->buf))
    ret = MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR;
  else
  {
    memcpy (mem, buf, size);
    ret = (ssize_t) size;
  }
  free (buf); /* Buf may be set even on error return. */
done:
  free (src);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function read_cb:
struct Holder
{
  FILE *file;
  z_stream stream;
  void *buf;
}
...
#define MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR ((ssize_t)-2)
...
#define MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_OF_STREAM ((ssize_t)-1)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions are used in the provided function. The code does not use compiler-specific constructs such as __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, statement-expressions, __builtin_*, __extension__, or other vendor-specific keywords/extension syntaxes that are explicitly documented as language extensions. The identifiers and functions in the fragment are standard C (malloc, free, fread, ferror, memcpy) or from standard headers (uint64_t from <stdint.h>, size_t from <stddef.h>/<stdio.h>), or from external libraries (z_stream from zlib) — none are compiler language extensions per se. The POSIX type ssize_t appears in the signature; ssize_t is a POSIX type rather than a compiler language-extension token. If the target compiler explicitly documents ssize_t (or any other used symbol) as a compiler language extension for the build environment in question, that platform-specific detail should be checked by reviewers — otherwise it is not a language extension covered by MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 and therefore not flagged here.
